block.p: New Swiss Guard Chief Is Found Slain in Vatican The newly appointed commander of the Pope's Swiss Guard, his wife and a younger Swiss Guard were found shot to death in the Vatican.

Arrests Lead to Powerful Lobby The arrests of four Cuban exiles aboard a cabin cruiser near Puerto Rico with a cache of illegal assault weapons last October prompted a Federal investigation that has led to the Cuban-American National Foundation, one of the most powerful lobbying groups in the United States.

Mayor to Challenge Netanyahu Tel Aviv's Mayor said he was forming a centrist party to neutralize the power of ''religious extremists'' and would challenge Benjamin Netanyahu for prime minister in 2000.

Albright Extends Mideast Talks Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright decided to remain in London to extend what she hoped would be decisive talks with Israeli and Palestinian leaders on restoring momentum to the search for peace.

Argentina Seeks Extradition An Argentine judge investigating allegations that I.B.M. gave Government officials up to $21 million in bribes in exchange for a lucrative bank contract said he would seek extradition of two current and two former I.B.M. executives if they refused to come to Buenos Aires to testify.

Indian Official Sees Threat India's Defense Minister, George Fernandes, has breached a longstanding taboo by declaring that China, not Pakistan, is India's chief potential threat. He also said India should formally declare itself a nuclear weapons state if a review of defense policy supports his view.

Beijing University's Birthday Beijing University celebrated its 100th anniversary in a scripted extravaganza featuring a speech by President Jiang Zemin. Although intellectuals say political discussions are making a comeback, police restricted access to the campus and the Government handpicked guests for the opening event.

Indonesia to Raise Prices Just hours before the International Monetary Fund unanimously approved restoring financial aid to Indonesia, President Suharto announced plans to raise the price of fuel and electricity by as much as 70 percent. The announcement fulfills commitments to the I.M.F. that the Government has long resisted, leaving many Indonesians shocked.

Italian Leader in Washington Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy is to arrive in Washington today as the first European leader to visit the United States since he and his counterparts went ahead with plans for the euro.
U.S. Soldier Attacked in Russia A black American marine was severely beaten by Russian skinheads in a wave of assaults against foreigners of African and Asian descent.

Judge Gives Unabomber 4 Consecutive Life Terms A Federal judge sentenced Theodore J. Kaczynski to four life sentences plus 30 years. At the hearing, the widow of one of the Unabomber's victims called Mr. Kaczynski a ''diabolical, evil, cunning murderer.''

McDougal Is Indicted A Federal grand jury in Arkansas indicted Susan H. McDougal on charges of criminal contempt and obstruction of justice after she declined to answer questions about the Clintons, her former partners in the Whitewater land venture. Ms. McDougal served 18 months for civil contempt, also for refusing to answer grand jury questions.
More than 10 hours of tape recordings of Webster L. Hubbell's prison conversations were released.

Trading for Judges President Clinton agreed to nominate a prominent conservative to a Federal appeals court post in exchange for confirmation of one of his nominees to the same court, Senate and Administration officials said.

Marine Hearing on Ski Lift Two marine officers who sat in the rear seats of a jet that clipped ski-lift cables in Italy, killing 20 people, face a military hearing today that will test the degree to which crew members can be punished for the actions of those around them.
$30 Million for a Homer William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman, paid more than $30 million for a Winslow Homer seascape, a record price for an American painting, experts in the art world said.

Restrictive Rules Rejected The Supreme Court rejected restrictive rules for a category of civil rights suits against public officials, spurning a lower court's effort to impose the rules and saying that judges should not change the law.
Initiative on Global Warming President Clinton announced a Government-industry initiative to reduce the gases that abet global warming, by making homes in the United States more fuel-efficient.

Holocaust Survivor Wins Swiss-Bank Settlement Estelle Sapir of Queens emerged as a rare victor in the tangled battle between Holocaust survivors and Swiss banks, accepting a settlement from Credit Suisse that by some estimates could total $500,000.

Funds Frozen for the Apollo Governor Pataki and Mayor Giuliani are refusing to provide more financial assistance to the Apollo Theater until the foundation that controls it answers questions about finances.
Air Bag Theft Indictments The authorities indicted six people in connection with the theft of thousands of car air bags in New York, New Jersey and the Northeast.

Union Upholds Trusteeship An appeals board of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees has upheld a decision to put the local representing 22,000 New York City school cafeteria workers and crossing guards into trusteeship, finding that its president improperly took $1.1 million.
N.C.A.A. Penalized $66 Million The N.C.A.A. was told to pay $66 million in triple damages for trying to limit the pay of assistant coaches.
'Ragtime' Leads Tony Nominees Nominations for the 52d annual Tony Awards were announced, with ''Ragtime'' getting 13, ''The Lion King'' 11 and ''Cabaret'' 10.
Entremed's Wild Ride Entremed, a small biomedical company that might have a drug that could lead to a cancer cure, rose $39.75, to close at $51.81; at one point, the price went above $80.

S.E.C.-Nationsbank Settlement The S.E.C. said Nationsbank, one of the largest financial institutions in the country, would pay almost $7 million to settle charges that it misled customers who bought two bond funds in 1993 and 1994.

$70 Million Web Deal The on-line directory service Excite will pay Netscape $70 million for the right to provide search services and other information that Netscape will offer to users of its browser software and Web home page.

Fed Governor to Depart Susan M. Phillips, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, said she would resign on June 30 to become dean of the School of Business and Public Management at George Washington University in Washington.
